title: From thesaurus to semantic network
text:
Partners





Team: 16 permanent members, 3 French laboratories, 4 Italian research departments and 3 Museums


The project involves 16 permanent members highly qualified coming from 3 French laboratories, 4 Italian University departments and 3 Museums. Master and PHD students are also included. The project is organised in three specific work-packages, based on the scheduled progression of scientific analysis from the Archaeometric , archaeological and technological analysis to the data modelling (WP3)
WP3 takes care of open-source data and tools to provide open access results, codes and data produced during the project as well as after their publication.This specific WP is dedicated to cultural networks analysis, from the object to society, by statistical approaches to get numerical indexes and conventional threshold helping to recognise consistent patterns in the dataset. The patterns modeled by spatial and phylogenetic networks are clustering with community/similarity methods and leveraging network to explore both material culture (chaînes opératoires) and the socio-economic dimension of the Protohistoric societies. The main goal is to be able to automatically order and spatially orient such complex and heterogeneous data and try to set out a dynamic typology of nested networks and sub-networks as well as different scenarios of the cultural and economic interactions. characterisation of Italic bronze craftsmanship in the Early Iron Age. With French, English and Italian, are the other official languages of this project.

title: From thesaurus to semantic network
text:
Social interactions and network analysis

Archaeological ContextDatasetSitesModeling social & cultural interactions




3 different but linked cultural areas: Golasecca, Ligurians and Western Emilia





1200 items made in copper alloys held in 3 different museums from 6 archaeological sites









Arm ring







Basket-shape pendent







Belt







Pendent









Settlements from 3 cultural areas and one Golasecca cemetery









Because the project focusing on north-Italian craft techniques, the archaeological context belonging to 3 different but linked cultural areas: Golasecca culture (north-eastern part of Piedmont), whose productions spread across the Alps in the Celtic area during the first iron age, Ligurians (Southern Piedmont) and indigenous communities living in the Etruscan area (Western Emilia). This part of northern Italy has been targeted by recent researches, publications and excavations while providing a renewed dataset and cultural framework to overcome the traditional archaeological approaches. Thanks to their good preservation, these artefacts and sites are a golden opportunity to produce an new investigation of Protohistoric metal crafting, and, taking an overview of the management of metal workshops by North Italic communities and their interactions with the Celtic world in
The dataset involve 1200 items made in copper alloys held in 3 different museums. This set is mostly composed of fibulae and clothing items covering a chronological range from the 7th to the end of the 5th century BC and belonging to the three cultural areas investigated. As cultural and social markers these items are a good ways to :


to identify the craft practices of copper alloy in Northern Italy (alloy/trace composition, isotopic origin, metallographic features)
establish the social and cultural impact of foreign metal finds and/or technological innovations in indigenous contexts
rethink Protohistoric networks by modelling the data at different scales from the micro one (objects) to the social dimension.


In order to better understand the practices and techniques of the artisans, the settlements especially those with a well-documented artisanal activity are highlighted, and distributed among the three cultural entities. The sites are characterized by local production and the integration of foreign models and styles and share a common clothing fashion. Located along the main natural communication paths, they are also privileged intermediaries of the medium and long-distance trade, both internal and external to the peninsula

text:
Thesaurus management

OpenThesoISO25964-1ISO25964-2














Opentheso is a multilingual, multi-paradigm thesaurus manager. Created in 2005. It supports poly-hierarchies in accordance with ISO25964 (25964-1 and 25964-2) Bibracte has shown that the ISO standard 25964 for the management of thesauri is sufficiently flexible to describe the different “points of view” presiding over the elaboration of the specialised and evolving “micro-languages” of archaeologists.

500 concepts related to protohistoric adornment and metallurgical technologies. * “fibule a sanguisuga” - alternative label: “Bogenfibel” - associated concept The wording is associated with “culture de Golasecca” and “féminin”, because these fibulae are the “prerogative of feminine clothing and characterise the burials of Golasecca women”. - references: “Cicolani 2017” points to the record of the indexed catalogue Frantiq (physical location); “Cicolani (V.)” refers to Veronica’s IdRef (~ authors) record and “Passeurs des Alpes…” allows, when it exists, to provide a link to the online documentary resource (Cairn). - iconography external resource directly downloadable from a perennial Nakala repository, one can reach iconographic documents. The conditions for sharing and reuse are specified in the metadata. Ark

DB record


The DBMS is a FileMaker server hosted in the Huma-Num structure for shared and restricted use among team members. This data structure will allow the durability of the storage and facilitate interfacing with research data already implemented by the scientific coordinator via Archeolocalis and the BaseFer database linked to AOROC Chronocarto web interface: http://www.chronocarto.eu/spip.php?article1&lang=fr. To increase the interoperability of the database, data and metadata will be transcribed on the fly by computer routines written in R and Python, with low-access (ODBC), or high-level access (SQL, GET).
